Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 34389  
September 2006  
 
 
 
 
Kingdom of Cambodia: Preparing the Financial Sector 
Development Program   
(Financed by the Japan Special Fund) 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Prepared by [Author(s)] 
 
[Firm] 
 
[Address]

      [Implementing Agency] 
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
 members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 11 September 2006) 
 
Currency Unit –  riel/s (KR)

$1.00 =  KR4,162.66 
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
FSPL  –  financial sector program loan 
GDP  –  gross domestic product 
IT  –  information technology 
KICPAA  –  Kampuchea Institute of Certified Public Accountants and 
Auditors 
MEF  –  Ministry of Economy and Finance 
MFI  –  microfinance institution 
NBC  –  National Bank of Cambodia 
PPTA  –  project preparatory technical assistance 
SDP  –  sector development program 
TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector  –  Finance 
Subsector  –  Finance sector development 
Themes  –  Sustainable economic growth and governance 
Subthemes  –  Promoting economic efficiency and enabling markets, 
financial and economic governance 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Vice President  C. Lawrence Greenwood, Jr., Operations Group 2 
Director General  R. Nag, Southeast Asia Department (SERD) 
Directors  J. Ahmed, Governance, Finance, and Trade Division, SERD 
  S. Bajpai, Country Director, Cambodia Resident Mission (CARM), 
SERD 
Team leader  S. Tukuafu, Financial Specialist, Governance, Finance, and Trade 
Division, SERD  
Team member  V. Hem, Economics and Finance Sector Officer, CARM, SERD

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of  Cambodia has requested technical assistance (TA) from Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) to design and prepare the Financial Sector Development Program  
(SDP). The outputs of the TA will include an SDP1 document that follows on from the Financial 
Sector Program Loan I (FSPL I)2 and is in line with the financial sector Blueprint for Cambodia 
(currently being updated).3 A TA grant of $650,0004 has been earmarked under the Japan 
Special Fund to prepare the SDP, expected to be approved in 2007. The TA Fact-Finding 
Mission5 visited Cambodia in May 2006 and had detailed consultations with the Government 
and  key  stakeholders  on  the  expected  overall  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  activities,  cost 
estimates, implementing arrangements, and terms of reference for consulting services. The 
findings of the Mission and understandings reached with the Government are reflected in this 
paper. The TA Design and Monitoring Framework is in Appendix 1 with achievements of the 
FSPL I in the Supplementary Appendix. The Initial Poverty and Social Analysis is in Appendix 2. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The development framework for Cambodia’s financial sector is based on the 2001–2010 
financial sector blueprint (the “Blueprint”) that was developed with ADB support and adopted by 
the Government in late 2001. Since implementation of the Blueprint, there has been progress in 
certain areas of the sector; in other areas, lessons have been learned from international and 
domestic experience. Those experiences, plus new challenges that have recently emerged, 
prompted the Government to request further support from ADB to update the Blueprint so that it 
may more accurately reflect the current situation. It is expected that the Blueprint update6 will be 
completed by the third quarter of 2006 and that the updated Blueprint will include an evaluation 
of activities to date, the framework for continued reform in the financial sector over the next 10 
years, and useful inputs for the design of the SDP.  
 
3.  Throughout the FSPL I implementation period, steady progress has been made towards 
achieving the program’s objectives even though the buildup for the general election in 2003 and 
the  one-year  delay  in  forming  the  new  National  Assembly  affected  implementation  during 
subprogram II. Reforms to date in a financial sector that is dominated by the banking subsector 
have helped to establish a relatively sound legal framework with strong prudential norms. This 
enabled the National Bank of Cambodia (NBC) to close down 16 nonviable banks in 2002 and 
raise the capital requirements for the remaining banks. Although there is now a relatively strong 
banking subsector and some growth in financial services, financial deepening and outreach 
remain challenges.  
 
4.  The performance of Cambodia’s financial sector has been satisfactory. The ratio of 
broad money supply (M2) to gross domestic product (GDP) has risen from 12.6% in 2000, 
before the start of the program, to 18.6% of GDP in 2005. Credit to the private sector has 
correspondingly risen from 6.4% of GDP in 2000 to an estimated 9.4% in 2005. Total deposits 
were close to 15% of GDP in 2005, compared with 9.5% of GDP in 2000. Despite these positive 
                                                 
1  The SDP will comprise an information technology project to computerize the National Bank of Cambodia and a 
policy-based component for a total loan of $33 million. The program component is expected to adopt the same 
program loan cluster approach that was successfully used for FSPL I. 
2  ADB. 2001. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on a Proposed Program Loan 
Cluster to the Kingdom of Cambodia for the Financial Sector Program. Manila. 
3  ADB. 2001. Cambodia: Financial Sector Blueprint for 2001–2010. Manila 
4  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 27 April 2006. 
5  The Mission comprised Samiuela Tukuafu (financial specialist/mission leader), and Vanndy Hem (economics and 
finance officer, CARM). 
6  ADB. 2005. Technical Assistance to the Kingdom of Cambodia for Financial Sector Blueprint Update. Manila.

2   
developments, there are still policy gaps, implementation challenges, and capacity constraints 
that need to be addressed in each of the subsectors, as noted below. 
 
5.  Banking. There are in Cambodia at present 15 commercial banks, 4 specialized banks 
(including the state-owned Rural Development Bank), and 2 representative offices of foreign-
based banks. All registered banks are adequately capitalized following the relicensing process 
that set the minimum capital requirement at $13 million equivalent (2002) and minimum capital 
adequacy  at  15%  (2004).  The  average  capital  adequacy  was  32%  and  overall  ratio  of 
nonperforming loans to total net loans was 7.5% at the end of 2005. Banks have been free to 
set their own interest rates since 1995, and the average annual interest rate spread tends to be 
high.  Spreads  were  around  12%  in  2005,  with  most  banks  maintaining  high liquidity.  The 
operations  of  individual  banks  need  to  be  reviewed  and  measures  taken  to  address  key 
governance structures, upgrade staff skills, encourage competition, and strengthen compliance 
with new statutory requirements (uniform chart of accounts, regular provision of prudential 
reports, anti-money laundering requirements, credit information sharing systems, publication of 
audited financial statements, and others). Apart from banking supervision, other areas requiring 
additional work include upgrading prudential requirements to international standards and best 
practices, improving skills of the NBC staff, as well as enhancing surveillance and enforcing 
regulations to ensure the safety of public deposits and integrity of the banking system. 
 
6.  Insurance. Of the three operating insurance firms, one is 100% state-owned. There is 
also a locally registered reinsurer that is 80% state-owned. State shares are held by the Ministry 
of Economy and Finance (MEF), but, since MEF is the regulator of insurance activities, an 
important reform item has been to try divesting those shares so that MEF can perform its 
regulatory functions equitably. The insurance sector, with a total premium income of only $10.5 
million (0.18% of GDP) in 2005, is still in its early stage of development, and the underlying 
concepts and business transactions are very new in Cambodia. The main insurance products 
available locally are those that address liabilities arising from construction work and public 
transport  accidents,  as  well  as  motor  vehicle  third  party  policies.  A  comprehensive  and 
transparent  legal  and  regulatory  framework  that  is  based  on  core  insurance  principles, 
international  best  practices,  and  tailored  training  support  programs  and  incentives  is  a 
prerequisite for growth. 
 
7.  While FSPL I has had some success in introducing a legal and regulatory framework, 
establishing the regulator within MEF and transforming insurance agents to fully functional 
insurance firms so as to compete with the state-owned insurance company have had mixed 
outcomes. Reorienting the Government’s role from sole operator to regulator has not been easy, 
as the required skills must be built up over time and regulatory enforcement has been weak. 
Pressing requirements include to upgrade prudential regulations to international standards, 
improve staff skills, encourage competition on a level playing field, strengthen surveillance, and 
enforce regulations. 
 
8.  Microfinance. Though small, the subsector has come a long way. As of March 2006, 
there  were  16  licensed  and  24  registered  microfinance  institutions  (MFIs)  that  were  not 
government operated. Active borrowers using micro business loans (average size of $182) 
numbered 89,176 clients at the end of 2004, and the figure for small business loans (average 
size of $1,720) was 25,984. There is potential for growth. Voluntary savings in MFIs are very 
small. NBC has established a supervisory unit for MFIs, and further support will be required to 
enhance its off-site and on-site capabilities. Integrating the microfinance subsector into the 
mainstream financial sector will be one of the solutions to the problem of formal access to 
financial services by small and medium enterprises and rural households. This will require 
education and public awareness services, rural outreach, and specially designed products and 
services for rural and low-income households.

3
 
9.  Interbank and Money Markets. Some progress has been made in developing interbank 
and money markets. Formal establishment of the Bankers Association helped in forming the 
Cambodia Institute of Banking, implementing the uniform chart of accounts, and developing the 
pilot system for sharing credit information among members. The law on negotiable instruments 
and payment transactions that was adopted by the National Assembly in 2005 provides the 
legal basis for further development of payment systems, introducing new negotiable instruments, 
and promoting development of a money market. Four implementing regulations have been 
developed, and support will be required for implementing the approved law and regulations. 
 
10.  Legal and Supporting Infrastructure. Key legislation has been adopted since the 2001 
commencement  of  the  FSPL  I  concerning  the  following  areas:  insurance,  accounting, 
commercial  enterprises,  negotiable  instruments  and  payment  transactions,  and  commercial 
arbitration.  The  process  of  getting  these  key  pieces  of  legislation  adopted  by  the  various 
committees of the Council of Ministers and National Assembly required more time than was 
initially envisaged under FSPL I. Currently under consideration at various levels of the approval 
chain are drafts for the following laws: secured transactions, insolvency, anti-money laundering, 
anticorruption, and leasing. All require technical assistance to help the lawmakers understand 
the underlying legal concepts and, in so doing, increase the likelihood that these laws will be 
adopted and implemented within the initial time plan. There is also a need to revise existing 
legislation to reflect the status of commercial development and practices in Cambodia. 
 
11.  Work has commenced under FSPL I, with complementary technical support from the 
World  Bank,  in  developing  accounting  and  auditing  practices.  The Kampuchea  Institute  of 
Certified Public Accountants and Auditors (KICPAA)7 has been established, and it has bylaws, a 
code of ethics, and key committee structures. Since there are approximately just 24 locally 
qualified members, KICPAA is seeking to increase its membership. Additional scholarships 
need  to  be  made  available  on  a  competitive  basis  to  build  a  core  of  qualified  members 
(estimated at 150) to enable KICPAA to function effectively. Similarly, key regulations to aid 
implementation of the Accounting Law need to be adopted and training needs to be provided for 
those who will be implementing them.  
 
12.  Information Technology (IT) Project for NBC. The NBC’s internal operating systems 
and processes are mostly manual. With growing responsibilities, increasing transactions volume, 
and the NBC serving a rising number of clients, the need for modernized operating systems and 
processes is urgent. With ADB support, the NBC in 2004 did its own assessment of its key 
functional departments’ IT needs. A final report was produced in late 2004 that supported 
modernization of NBC’s key operations: payment and settlement, internal accounting, foreign 
reserves management, economic and financial databases for economic research, and bank 
supervision. A detailed feasibility study is needed to determine the specific IT requirements of 
each  department,  appropriate  software  and  hardware,  and  the  associated  costs.  This  will 
provide the basis for NBC to determine which of those activities can be financed out of the 
project loan from ADB, the implementation schedule, procurement arrangements, and other 
financing sources. 
                                                 
7  The  United  Kingdom-based  Association  of  Chartered  Certified  Accountants  (ACCA)  provides  a  3.5-year 
accreditation program for KICPAA. A memorandum of cooperation between the National Accounting Council, 
KICPAA, and CPA Australia was signed in May 2006.

4   
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
13.  The impact is improved financial intermediation and sustainable economic growth. The 
expected outcome will be improved soundness and efficiency of the financial system. The SDP 
will focus on (i) the banking, insurance, and microfinance subsectors; (ii) the related legal and 
regulatory framework; (iii) interbank and money market development; (iv) strengthening financial 
market infrastructure; and (v) modernizing the NBC’s key operating systems and processes. 
Thereby, it will support the Government’s ongoing reform efforts that aim to address governance 
and corruption issues, problems with access to finance, high transaction costs, limited access to 
quality information, staff capacity, and increasing competition in what should be a level playing 
field.  
 
14.  The program design will take into account strategies for private sector development and 
provide a focused and sequenced series of policy measures consistent with and supplementary 
to the Government’s overall framework for reform as stated in the 10-year Financial Sector 
Blueprint (updated). The project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) is expected to deliver 
the following outputs: 
(i)  A policy matrix and action plan for further development of the financial sector, 
with estimated adjustment costs and a financing plan (including a development 
policy letter from the Government). 
(ii)  A  design  and  monitoring  framework  that  identifies  inputs,  activities,  outputs, 
outcomes, and impact of the proposed SDP, including risks and measures to 
mitigate those risks, baseline data and mechanism for regular monitoring and 
reporting. 
(iii)  Awareness-  and  consensus-building  workshops  and  seminars  with  key 
stakeholders in Government, the private sector, and the donor community to 
produce a final report reflecting the structure of the program as discussed and 
agreed to with all stakeholders. 
(iv)  A program administration manual to guide the Government in implementing the 
policy conditions. 
(v)  The design of implementation arrangements and capacity building to ensure that 
policy conditions are implemented in an appropriate, consistent, and coordinated 
manner. 
(vi)  A project loan design (in a design and monitoring framework reflecting a cost and 
benefit  analysis  conducted  in  accordance  with  ADB  requirements,  inputs, 
activities, outputs, outcomes and impact, risks and measures to mitigate those 
risks) to help computerize key operating functions of the NBC. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
15.  The PPTA will draw on the Blueprint update and include an evaluation of the results of 
FSPL I. An integral part of the PPTA will be to ensure active dialogue with key policymakers and 
other public and private sector stakeholders in the financial sector. Findings, program and 
project  proposals,  and  other  deliverables  will  be  presented  and  discussed  regularly  with 
policymakers and other stakeholders. Workshops will be organized with the executing agency, 
implementing agencies, and related stakeholders to adopt the final report and program design 
by April 2007.

5
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost a total of $775,000 equivalent, of which ADB will provide 
$650,000. The TA will be financed on a grant basis from the Japan Special Fund, financed by 
the Government of Japan. The Government will finance the remaining $125,000 equivalent that 
includes  provision  of  counterpart  staff,  office  space,  administrative  support,  and  other 
miscellaneous  services.  The  cost  estimates  and  financing  plan  are  in  Appendix  3.  The 
Government has been informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance an 
ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  The  NBC  will  be  the  Executing  Agency  responsible  for  overall  coordination  of  TA 
activities. NBC and relevant departments within NBC will be the implementing agencies for the 
banking and microfinance subsectors, related regulations, supervisory functions, payment and 
settlement systems, interbank and money markets, training institutes, and the IT project. MEF 
will be the implementing agency for the insurance subsector, as well as for accounting and 
auditing components. The Ministry of Commerce will be the implementing agency for developing 
the legal and regulatory framework and for related components. Each implementing agency will 
provide office space, counterpart staff, and other support services to the consultants. 
 
18.  The TA is scheduled to commence on 1 September 2006 and is to be implemented over 
a period of 12 months. The consulting services comprise 20 person-months of international and 
18 person-months of domestic consulting input. Terms of reference for the consultants are in 
Appendix 4. Experience in Cambodia has shown that firms, as opposed to individuals, have 
been more expensive and have not been successful in recruiting the right mix of consultants, 
especially  when  the  project  requires  a  diverse  set  of  expertise.  For  this  reason,  a  team 
comprising individual international and national consultants and an international consulting firm 
will be used. Three of the international consultants (Central Banking Expert, IT Systems Design 
Expert, and Accounting Expert), who will together contribute 9 person-months of international 
consulting services, and one national consultant (IT Expert) who will contribute 6 person-months 
of national consulting services, will be engaged by ADB on an individual basis. The remaining 
11 person-months of international and 12 person-months of national consulting services will be 
contracted out to a consulting firm with a budget allocation of about $380,000. Quality- and cost-
based selection procedures and a simplified technical proposal will follow, and consultants will 
be selected in accordance with ADB guidelines.8  
 
19.  The team leader will be responsible for preparing a detailed work plan before the start of 
services, which will include a timetable for deliverables defined under each component of the TA. 
The consultants will submit interim reports for review by ADB as well as the executing and 
implementing agencies and a draft final report, following which tripartite meetings will be held to 
finalize the report. The final report will be submitted by April 2007 and will incorporate comments 
from the executing and implementing agencies and ADB during and after the tripartite meetings.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $650,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Cambodia for preparing the Financial Sector Development Program, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board. 
  
                                                 
8  ADB. 2005. Guidelines on the Use of Consultants by ADB and Its Borrowers. Manila.

10  Appendix 2 
INITIAL POVERTY AND SOCIAL ANALYSIS  
A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis 
       
Is the sector identified as a national   Yes  Is the sector identified as a national   Yes 
priority in country poverty analysis?     priority in country poverty partnership   
    No  agreement?    No 
 
Contribution of the sector to reduce poverty in Cambodia: 
 
The project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) will help prepare the Financial Sector Development 
Program (SDP) document. The SDP is expected to further increase commercial activities and financial 
intermediation by promoting development of a sound, market-based financial system to enhance the 
potential for economic growth and creating employment. Benefits of the SDP will include improved access 
to  financial  services  and  a  more  competitive,  diversified  financial  sector  that  reduces  systemic 
vulnerabilities. These benefits will be substantial and include (i) strengthening of the legal and regulatory 
infrastructure, as well as accounting and auditing practices; (ii) capacity building in the banking, insurance, 
and microfinance subsectors, as well as in the various supervisory institutions; (iii) further development of 
the insurance and microfinance subsectors; and (iv) modernization of key functions at the National Bank of 
Cambodia  (NBC)  that  include  the  payment  and  settlement  systems.  A  wider  cross  section  of  the 
population will benefit from an environment that is conducive to financial sector development. That 
development will be supported by (i) effective legal and regulatory reforms, (ii) well skilled employees and 
a highly developed accounting profession, (iii) expanded credit from the banking subsectors to support 
economic activities, and (iv) the concomitant growth of such nonbank subsectors as insurance and 
microfinance. Beneficiaries are expected to include the poor and near poor. A broader and more balanced 
financial system will be more resilient to external shocks (which have serious implications for the poor). 
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Targeting Classification: General intervention 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
 
Consultants will review previous and recent poverty studies to determine financial services needs and understand the 
issues affecting provision of those services. Focus will be on the roles of microfinance institutions and the effects of 
high transaction costs, accessibility to low-cost finance, and savings opportunities among poor and rural households. 
 
 
C.  Participation Process 
 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?   Yes    No  
 
Stakeholder analysis will focus on the impact of the Financial Sector Program Loan I on the Executing Agency (NBC) 
and implementing agencies (Ministry of Economy and Finance, Ministry of Commerce, the state-owned Cambodia 
National Insurance Company, Bankers Association, and training institutes), as well as on the staff capacities of these 
key institutions.  
 
Is there a participation strategy?    Yes           No 
 
Series of workshops and roundtable discussions with the NBC, Ministry of Economy and Finance, Ministry of 
Commerce, other related Government agencies, development partners, and other key stakeholders to build 
awareness and consensus on the proposed policy actions for the various subsectors and components of the SDP. 
 
D.  Gender Development 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: No specific strategy required. Will leave the market forces to work. 
 
Has an output been prepared?    Yes    No

Appendix 4          13   
 
 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
  
A.  International Consulting Firm 
1.  Financial Sector Expert and Team Leader (5.5 person-months, international) 
1.  The international expert and team leader must have expertise in finance, extensive work 
experience  in  various  areas  of  the  financial  sector  (e.g.,  banking  and  microfinance),  and 
familiarity  with  international  standards  and  best  practices.  Prior  experience  in  preparing  a 
program loan and familiarity with the Cambodian financial sector will be advantages. The expert 
will undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Study the Financial Sector Blueprint for 2001–2010, draft Blueprint update and 
related reports of TA 4677-CAM consultants, various reports relating to the 1st 
Financial Sector Program, and other documents relating to Cambodia’s financial 
sector. 
(ii)  Prepare a draft inception report together with an implementation plan outlining 
the activities to be undertaken by the team or individual consultants, objectives of 
those activities, expected outputs, and timelines for delivering those outputs. The 
draft inception report will be discussed jointly with the Government (executing 
and implementing agencies) and Asian Development Bank (ADB) Mission during 
the Project Preparatory Technical Assistance (PPTA) Inception Mission. 
(iii)  Upon approval of the inception report, organize and lead consultations with key 
players in the financial sector (banking, insurance, and microfinance subsectors; 
regulators;  related  associations  and  professional  bodies;  training  institutions; 
dispute resolution institutions) and related stakeholders (Government ministries 
and agencies, development partners, technical consultants, etc). Coordinate and 
monitor progress of the PPTA implementation plan to ensure that members of 
the consultant team are able to deliver their expected outputs on time. 
(iv)  Under item (iii) above, evaluate developments in the banking subsector (covering 
individual  banks)  in  terms  of  soundness,  depth,  compliance  with  statutory 
requirements (supervisory regime), competition, human resource capacity, and 
customer perception. Analyze progress to date and identify gaps to address, 
including an estimate of the associated adjustment costs. Prepare a report on 
findings,  including  a  section  covering  the  impact  of  the  first  financial  sector 
program loan (FSPL I) on the financial sector. 
(v)  Through a consultative process and in close coordination with the PPTA team, 
design the SDP structure (using the Technical Assistance Design and Monitoring 
Framework). Consolidate the consultant team’s reports on each subsector and 
policy prescriptions, adjustment costs, macroeconomic context including baseline 
data, program benefits, risks and proposed measures to mitigate those risks, 
proposed implementation arrangements, ADB safeguard policies, etc. 
(vi)  Through a consultative process and with assistance from the central banking 
expert and relevant PPTA team members, design the structure of the information 
technology project to computerize National Bank of Cambodia (using the Design 
and Monitoring Framework). Consolidate individual consultant reports on each 
component, including project benefits, risks and proposed measures to mitigate 
those risks, proposed procurement and implementation arrangements, etc.

14  Appendix 4 
 
(vii)  Provide  inception,  interim,  and  final  reports  (final  report  by  April  2007),  as 
required, to National Bank of Cambodia (NBC) and ADB and organize meetings 
and/or workshops to discuss those reports and obtain Government endorsement. 
 
2.  Legal Expert (2 person-months, international) 
2.  The expert must have a legal background in finance and commerce with extensive work 
experience in commercial banking, payment and settlements, and/or insurance. Familiarity with 
the legal and regulatory framework for banking, finance, and commerce in Cambodia will be an 
advantage. The expert will undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Focusing on legal and regulatory aspects, study the Financial Sector Blueprint for 
2001-2010,  draft  Blueprint  update  and  related  reports  of  TA  4677-CAM 
consultants, various reports relating to the 1st Financial Sector Program, and 
other documents relating to Cambodia’s financial sector. Identify additional laws 
and regulations that should be developed to facilitate financial and commercial 
activities. 
(ii)  In consultation with relevant stakeholders, evaluate implementation of the various 
laws and accompanying regulations relating to the financial sector that have 
been  approved  to  date  and  identify  gaps  and  deficiencies  that  need  to  be 
addressed to enhance their effectiveness. 
(iii)  Prepare a report (including an evaluation of the impact of FSPL I on the legal and 
regulatory framework for banking, finance, and commerce) on the current legal 
and  regulatory  framework,  judicial  and  dispute  resolution  processes  for 
commercial transactions, required changes or improvements, the rationale for the 
proposed  changes,  estimated  adjustment  costs,  and  ways  to  expedite  the 
proposed changes. Assist the team leader in securing the Government’s and 
other related stakeholders’ approval of the report. 
 
3.  Insurance Expert (1.5 person-months, international) 
3.  The  international  insurance  expert  must  have  extensive  knowledge  and  hands-on 
experience in insurance market development, regulations, and supervision. Familiarity with the 
international core principles of insurance, as well as the legal and regulatory framework for 
insurance in Cambodia and the region will be an advantage. The expert will undertake the 
following tasks: 
 
(i)  Focusing on the insurance subsector, study the Financial Sector Blueprint for 
2001-2010,  draft  Blueprint  update  and  related  reports  of  TA  4677-CAM 
consultants, various reports relating to the 1st Financial Sector Program, and 
other documents relating to Cambodia’s financial sector. 
(ii)  In  consultation  with  relevant  stakeholders,  evaluate  the  developments  in  the 
insurance subsector in terms of soundness, depth, compliance with statutory 
requirements (supervisory regime), competition, human resource capacity, and 
customer perception while identifying gaps that need to be addressed. 
(iii)  Prepare a report that will include the background to the insurance industry and 
regulatory regime; an evaluation of the impact of FSPL I on insurance market 
development, regulations, and supervision; proposed changes or improvements; 
the rationale for the proposed changes; estimated adjustment costs; and ways to 
expedite those changes. Assist the team leader in securing the Government’s 
and other related stakeholders’ approval of the report.

Appendix 4  15 
4.  Microfinance Expert (2 person-months, international) 
4.  The international microfinance expert must have extensive knowledge and hands-on 
experience in microfinance development, regulations, and supervision. Familiarity with the legal 
and regulatory framework for rural and microfinance in Cambodia will be an advantage. The 
international expert will undertake the following tasks:  
    
(i)  Focusing on the rural and microfinance subsector, study the Financial Sector 
Blueprint for 2001-2010, draft Blueprint update and related reports of TA 4677-
CAM consultants, various reports relating to the 1st Financial Sector Program, 
and any other documents relating to Cambodia’s financial sector. 
(ii)  In consultation with relevant stakeholders, evaluate developments in the rural 
and  microfinance  subsector  in  terms  of  soundness,  depth,  compliance  with 
statutory  requirements  (supervisory  regime),  competition,  human  resource 
capacity,  and  customer  perception  while  identifying  gaps  that  need  to  be 
addressed. 
(iii)  Prepare a report that will include the background to the rural and microfinance 
industry  and  regulatory  regime;  an  evaluation  of  the  impact  of  FSPL  I  on 
microfinance development, regulations, and supervision; proposed changes or 
improvements, including ways to improve outreach of microfinance services; the 
rationale for the proposed changes; estimated adjustment costs; and ways to 
expedite those changes. Assist the team leader in securing the Government’s 
and other related stakeholders’ approval of the report.  
 
5.  Financial  Sector  Expert  (7  person-months,  national),  Insurance  Expert  (2 
person-months, national) , and Legal Expert (3 person-months, national) 
5.  The national financial sector expert will serve as assistant to the team leader and the 
international microfinance expert. He or she will be required to have a background in finance 
and some working knowledge of banking and microfinance. The national insurance expert will 
serve  as  assistant  to  the  international  insurance  expert  and  should  have  some  working 
knowledge of insurance operations and an understanding of the insurance subsector. The 
national legal expert will serve as assistant to the international legal expert and will be required 
to have a background in law and/or commerce. Besides having proficiency in English, prior work 
experience with international consultants or organizations will be an advantage. In addition, the 
experts will undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Assist the respective international experts in all aspects of their tasks within the 
terms of reference, including project coordination and logistics. 
(ii)  Under the guidance of the international experts, gather and analyze the required 
information and data, and ensure that reports are available in English. 
(iii)  Conduct research on specific topics as required by the international experts. 
(iv)  Act as translators/interpreters for the international experts and ADB missions, 
when required.

16  Appendix 4 
 
B.  Individual Consultants 
1.  Central Banking Expert (3 person-months, international) 
 6.  The international central banking expert must have extensive knowledge and hands-on 
experience  in  central  banking  operations  and  procedures.  Familiarity  with  the  legal  and 
regulatory framework for the NBC will be an advantage. The expert, over two field visits, will 
undertake the following tasks: 
  
(i)  Focusing on the NBC, review its legal and regulatory framework, associated 
prakas,  organization  structure,  operating  policies  and  procedures,  functional 
departments,  previous  reports  on  its  operations,  and  any  other  reports  or 
documents relating to the NBC and its immediate clients. 
(ii)  In consultation with management, department heads, staff, and NBC clients, 
evaluate operational activities of the key departments in terms of processes, 
procedures, staff capacity, as well as effectiveness and efficiency of delivery 
while identifying gaps needing to be addressed. Prepare a report that will include 
the  background;  an  evaluation  of  the  impact  of  FSPL  I  on  central  banking 
operations and procedures; proposed changes or improvements; the rationale for 
the proposed changes; estimated adjustment costs; and ways to expedite those 
changes. 
(iii)  Through a consultative process and in close coordination with the international 
information technology (IT) systems design expert, design the structure of the IT 
project  that  will  computerize  the  NBC  (using  the  Design  and  Monitoring 
Framework). Consolidate the individual consultants’ reports on each component, 
including project benefits, risks and proposed measures to mitigate those risks, 
detailed  costs  and  a  financing  plan  according  to  ADB  guidelines,  proposed 
procurement and implementation arrangements, ADB safeguard policies, etc. 
(iv)  Through (i) and (ii) above, contribute to the work of the other consultants and 
team leader that relates to banking and microfinance supervision. Assist the 
team  leader  in  securing  the  Government’s  and  other  related  stakeholders’ 
approval of the report.  
 
2.  IT Systems Design Expert (3 person-months, international) 
7.  The  international  IT  systems  design  expert  must  have  a  strong  background  and 
extensive  hands-on  experience  in  computer  systems  analysis  and  design.  Familiarity  with 
IT-related banking and central banking work in the region, including Cambodia, will be an 
advantage. The expert, over two field visits, will undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Through consultation with the management, heads of departments, staff, and 
NBC’s  immediate  clients,  become  familiar  with  the  functional  arrangements, 
operating policies, processes, and procedures of the NBC while undertaking a 
feasibility study of the IT needs of each NBC department.  
(ii)  Prepare a report covering the IT software and hardware currently in use, service 
support available to NBC, the IT market within Cambodia, required IT system 
changes  or  improvements,  the  rationale  for  the  proposed  changes  or 
improvements, detailed costs by components, and any other related details. 
(iii)  Discuss the findings with NBC and obtain consent on the key functions that can 
be  financed  from  the  ADB  loan.  Design  detailed  IT  specifications  for  the 
approved key functions and identify potential suppliers. Assist NBC to prepare 
bidding documents.

Appendix 4  17 
(iv)  Assist the central banking expert and team leader in putting together the IT 
project document and discussing it with the NBC, Government, and other related 
stakeholders to secure their approval.  
 
3.  Accounting Expert (3 person-months, international) 
8.  The  international  accounting  expert  must  be  a  chartered  accountant  with  extensive 
hands-on experience in accounting and auditing development, international standards, and best 
practices. Familiarity with the accounting and auditing practices and developments in the region, 
including Cambodia, and ADB financial guidelines will be an advantage. The expert, over two 
field visits, will undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  In  consultation  with  all  stakeholders  on  accounting  and  auditing  practices,1 
evaluate  the  current  accounting  and  auditing  framework,  standards,  and 
practices against international standards and best practices. Assess the legal 
and  regulatory  framework,  institutional  arrangements,  domestic  capacity, 
enforcement mechanisms, training, and curriculum to determine how supportive 
these structures are of the accounting and auditing practices.  
(ii)  Undertake  a  due  diligence  assessment  of  the  public  financial  management 
system in terms of how well the system supports the flow of funds from the 
program and project loans. Identify gaps that need to be addressed.  
(iii)  Prepare a detailed report on the findings that will include an evaluation of the 
impact of FSPL I on accounting and auditing development, background, needed 
changes or improvements, the rationale for the proposed changes, estimated 
adjustment costs, and ways to expedite those changes. 
(iv)  Contribute to the work of the other consultants and team leader that relates to the 
accounting and auditing practices within banks, insurance firms, microfinance 
institutions, the NBC, and the public financial sector in general. Assist the team 
leader in securing the Government’s and other related stakeholders’ approval of 
the report. 
 
4.  IT Expert (6 person-months, national) 
9.  The national IT expert will be required to have a background in accounting and IT, some 
working knowledge of IT development and/or accounting operations, and proficiency in English. 
Prior work experience with international consultants or organizations will be an advantage. The 
expert will undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Assist the international IT and accounting experts in all aspects of their assigned 
terms of reference, including all matters of project coordination and logistics. 
(ii)  Conduct research on specific topics relating to the project, as required by the 
international experts. 
(iii)  Under the guidance of the international experts, gather and analyze the required 
information and data, and ensure that a report on the information and data is 
available in English. 
(iv)  Assist  the  international  experts  in  organizing  workshops  and  roundtable 
meetings,  preparing  materials  for  workshops  and  roundtable  meetings,  and 
providing translation support. 
                                                 
1  Ministry  of  Economy  and  Finance,  National  Accounting  Council,  Kampuchea  Institute  of  Certified  Public 
Accountants and Auditors, accounting firms, training institutes, banks, insurance companies, and microfinance 
institutions.
